subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: New member- and help with Macs?
msgSnippet: ... I have had success in getting the Unicode font to display in Safari, but only if the HTML file specifically indicates that it is to be used.  After
messageBody:
On 19 Jul 2006, at 11:18, meosongrey wrote:
> I have close to zero programming experience, so I don't really know
> how to make the
> fonts appear in either Safari or Internet Explorer. I tried
> changing the font Preferences
> in Safari to one the Kingsley, and ended up with all of my
> Microsoft Outlook inbox
> written in that font--but nothing that was supposed to be written
> in that font
> appearing correct.
>
> How should I go about mixing both Roman for where Roman is written
> on the internet
> with one of the Shavian/Quikscript fonts? As an aside, when I tried
> to download the
> one through Yahoo, it never got past the "initiating download
> stage", though I will try
> again later today.

I have had success in getting the Unicode font to display in Safari,
but only if the HTML file specifically indicates that it is to be
used. After installing the Kingsley.ttf file that I recently
uploaded, you can try this test page:
http://slate.langan.net/QS_unicode_sample.html
It is simply the HTML-marked-up version of the text file which I
posted to the files section.

However, that file does NOT display properly in Firefox, at least not
for me. All my fonts are screwed up (slightly) in Firefox, perhaps
because I am using the Cross-Platform Portable version.

oliver
